title: ADHA
abstract: Data layouts play a crucial role in determining the performance of a given application running on a given architecture. Existing parallel programming frameworks for both multicore and heterogeneous systems leave the onus of selecting a data layout to the programmer. Therefore, shifting the burden of data layout selection to optimizing compilers can greatly enhance programmer productivity and application performance. In this work, we introduce ADHA: a two-level hierarchal formulation of the data layout problem for modern heterogeneous architectures. We have created a reference implementation of ADHA in the Heterogeneous Habanero-C (H2C) parallel programming system. ADHA shows significant performance benefits of up to 6.92× compared to manually specified layouts for two benchmark programs running on a CPU+GPU heterogeneous platform.

motivations: Existing parallel programming frameworks require manual selection of data layouts, which can be time-consuming and impact application performance.
Programmer productivity and application performance can be improved by automating the selection of optimal data layouts.
objectives: Develop a formulation to automate the selection of optimal data layouts for heterogeneous architectures.
Integrate the formulation into a parallel programming system to enhance programmer productivity and application performance.
methods: Design a two-level hierarchical formulation of the data layout problem for modern heterogeneous architectures.
Implement the formulation in a parallel programming system, specifically Heterogeneous Habanero-C (H2C).
results: Achieve significant performance benefits by automating the selection of optimal data layouts.
Demonstrate the effectiveness of the formulation using benchmark programs on a CPU+GPU heterogeneous platform.
